description: maybe if devs provide their personal info on this page ill reconsider
Not usable without registration.

Granted, I'm using the free version. Cannot add a key from my local ~/.ssh folder for starters, as I get an access denied from the snap (making it and its contents world readable, just to test this, did not help). Furthermore, cannot connect to KVM guests using the generated names such as "machine.local" though IP address works fine. Interface is confusing/inconvenient, as you can't get to the keychain preferences using the menu bar, but have to use the down arrow. When I get there, I can import my private key file (id_rsa) using the File dialog, but if I want my public key, I have to paste it in from a text editor as no file dialog option is available. Apparently, I don't have the same idea how this should work as the developers do. I really wanted to like this, too. In short, when it works, it seems to work great, but getting it to work is more trouble than just using the command-line to begin with, so it kind of defeats the whole point. If these things get amended, then I'll happily reconsider.

Really nice interface, and relevant feature including SFTP. But honestly, 10 bucks a month! Netflix cost 10 buck a month, so to pay the equivalent for a SSH terminal software is out-of-the-question. 
I would have been happy to pay a one-time ~20 dollars, but really can't see how the subscription model works here.

If you're a student you have access to the premium version for free. It's a lot better than doing most of it manually with the protocal in the terminal. My school recommended that I use some other stuff that seems out of date in comparision. 

I've never seen a better UI for SSH and SFTP clients, but I think once I graduate I might uninstall to avoid the monthly payment for sftp.

description:
I have been using Termius on Windows 10 for a couple of years, Windows 11 and Ubuntu for the last year. When I started using the app it was possible to use it as a stand alone app for free or as a pay for app to network it. I used the stand alone version for a very long time. I have been using the pay for version for the last two years. Here's my $0.02.
The networked version is great if you have many machines you need access to. I have a few servers in my home lab with lots of cpu, memory, and disk space which allows me a fairly large Red Hat virtual lab running across three ProxMox data centers. I also keep a Windows 2016 AD domain and run some machines on Hyper-V. To a lesser extent, I keep a few machines on a VirtualBox lab and a VMWare Workstation 17 lab. 
In all cases, I divide my labs into Termius groups to make the numbers managable. Termius is sweet as I just installed this Ubuntu workstation client on my Dell Workstation as a Hyper-V virtual machine. I added Termius and logged in and had instant access to all of my linux and BSD boxes via ssh.
My one reservation is: I don't like the preset Hot Key Ctl+L. This is set to Local Terminal in Windows instead of clear terminal as is common in a Linux terminal. I had to turn off the Hot Key function as it was making me crazy every time it launched a local terminal.
 I don't like paying for the app either but developers have to eat too. Try to keep your perspective. If you download an app for free and you like the app enough to using regularly then you should buy them a cup of coffee or two every now and then. I certainly don't mind paying a reasonable amount to use a nice app. I pay for Office360, Red Hat Developer, Wikipedia, ProxMox, BeeKeeper, DropBox, VMWare, fre:ac, rufus, AIMP, Notepad++, Mozilla, Ubuntu, Debian, Putty and other apps I use on a regular basis. Free isn't free as there is a cost built in there somewhere. Remeber, someone spent a lot of time to make that nice OS or App you are using. They also spend a lot of time answering your questions and fixing bugs or adding features you request.
Paid app.. uninstalling it..

description: BAD without regristration
Can't do anything without registration and instandtly tries to advertise for another product. Just useless.

I started using this years ago when I was looking for a Linux version of SecureCRT that I had been using at work. It has grown a lot over the years and provides a lot of useful functionality. Not super thrilled about giving out an email address, but I figured it would be necessary if I decided to purchase it anyway, so I gave them an alias. Worked well, bought the program, renewed it several times over the years, still using my email alias, has become quite useful both on my laptop and my phone

I'm reading all of the other reviews calling it a 'scam' because it's not open source or you need to make an account. Of course you do, it's a CLOUD SSH client. I get this for free through the GitHub Student Developer Pack and it's super useful because all of my keys sync and hosts sync and it's a really good app. I dislike the fact that they only seem to care about Debian & Ubuntu based distros and you need to build the RPM using alien and rpm-build as described in this fedoraproject meta forum post: https://discussion.fedoraproject.org/t/deb-to-rpm-conversion-with-alien-not-working/72504/2

Otherwise, I love it.
